title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code, by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by adding new diseases presumed to be service-connected, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis. It also grants authority for administrative determination of presumption of service connection for these additional diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" adds new diseases like heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis to be presumed as service-connected. It also authorizes administrative determination for additional diseases. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on sound medical evidence and recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. The Secretary considers recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War and other medical information when determining service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. The association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is deemed positive if credible evidence supports it. The Secretary considers recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. If credible evidence supports the association between a disease and being a prisoner of war, a presumption of service connection may be warranted. The Secretary will determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease. If warranted, proposed regulations will be issued within 60 days. If not warranted, a notice will be published in the Federal Register with an explanation. If a disease already has a presumption, regulations will be proposed to remove it within 60 days of the determination. The Secretary will issue proposed regulations within 60 days if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease. If not warranted, regulations will be proposed to remove the presumption within 60 days. Veterans awarded compensation based on the presumption before its removal will continue to receive compensation. When a disease is removed from regulations, veterans and survivors will still be entitled to receive compensation.
